name: Baby steps
intro: Welcome to the world of combinators!
See the introduction for how stuff works here.
A short reminder of the rules:
• I x evaluates to x;
• K x y evaluates to x;
• S f g x evaluates to f x (g x);
• and all of the above only happens at the beginning of a (sub-)expression.
On the right you can see a list of available terms and their definitions,
it will be slowly extending as more quests are being completed.
Let's dive right in!

name: Swing, swing!
intro: Let's move some arguments around.
Just like in many chess and math problems, work backwards:
what λ-expression do you want to see before applying to the last argument?
Then construct it via the above technique and go one argument back,
until you run out of them.

name: The BCKW forest
intro: As you progress discovering more and more combinators,
you find out that some of them can thrive on their own.
In fact, as you wander further, you find yourself surrounded by a think forest
built entirely of four combinators:
B, C, K, and W.
Can you find the way back?
See also: BCKW system
on wikipedia.

name: The island of Iota
intro: Now you know two bases: the SK(I) and the BCKW.
Apparently, there is a one element base: X = x → xSK. Try it!

name: Boolean logic
intro: K and KI terms may be interpreted as true and false
, respectively, as K then else will result in then
and KI then else will result in else.
The trick is almost always to feed a function to a boolean value, and not the other way around.

name: More than a bit
intro: Another weird combinator base is MTAB.
Just like the BCKW system, it consists of four combinators,
representing repetition, transposition, discarding, and composition, respectively:
M a = a, T a b = b a, A a b = b,
and B a b c = a (b c).
Your task is to go back to BCKW from here. Good luck!

name: Recursion
intro: Recursive functions can be expressed in combinators, however, they cannot refer to themselves by name.
Instead, such function has to be passed to itself as an argument.
Let's say we want to find f such that f x = expr f x
for a given expression expr and arbitrary x.
This cannot be done directly because f appears in both parts of the equation.
We have, however, a couple tricks
somewhat in the spirit of separation of variables in differential equations.
First, let's assume that f = g g for some g.
(btw, can you prove that at least one such g exists for any given f?)
The equation thus becomes g g x = expr (g g) x,
but it still contains g on both sides.
Second, instead of looking for g itself, we look for a g0
satisfying g0 g x = expr (g g) x for any g
(including, of course, g0).
Now this can be solved for g0 using the methods from the previous quests,
and the function with the required properties is then f = g0 g0.
Side note: C(KM) g x, or cross constant mocker, may be used in place of g g
to defer evaluation. This can radically decrease computation time, or even avoid an infinite loop.

name: The Church of Numerals
intro: As everything in the world of combinators is a function, numbers are functions, too.
A Church numeral (named after
Alonzo Church)
is a function N that takes 2 arguments, x and y,
and returns x(...N times...(x(y))...).
By that definition, 0 is KI (just as false),
as it repeats the first argument exactly 0 times,
and 1 is I (easy to confuse).

name: Least List Lost Last
intro: Since there's a pair(x, y) operation in combinatory logic, one can already construct linked lists:
(V x V(y (V z KI))).
Such approach is very straightforward but requires explicit recursion for almost all operations.
There is, however, another way.
Much like Church numerals, lists can be encoded as parametric higher order functions:
[a, b, c] f x = f a (f b (f c x)).
So a list in this notation is indistinguishable from its fold operation
(or foldr more specifically).
We won't (yet) extend the notation with the [ and ];
you can find such syntactic sugar in your favourite programming language.
Instead, we'll use nil to denote an empty list and list val tail for a list node,
where tail is either another node, or nil.
So (list a (list b (list c nil))) f x evaluates to f a (f b (f c x))
and nil f x evaluates to just x.
